I believe the resource of Backdrop itself should be free. Open source is the future. Those with development skills should have no trouble making money through services / website development for those who won't or can't do it for themselves (most of the world). Figure into your pricing a 5% donation to support the platform that you're using to make money. Use that money to support better documentation of your projects or you could figure documentation costs/time into your pricing and charge the customer for the documentation they will need in the future.

Essentially, that 5% you will use to pay yourself for ongoing support of the developments you needed for your customers that were not yet available as a Backdrop resource (theme or module, etc.) Or you could use that 5% you set aside to pay another developer to maintain your contribution. We should just have the attitude to give back. In my case, I have much more time than money, so I donate my time to move many of my interests forward.

Consider creating a marketplace for website development services within the Backdrop ecosystem so that people who need help can find those developers who want to offer free services to non-profits/needy projects or offer real-world pricing to companies that are funded to pay for such services. Everybody wins.

@Sarvasri I think a lot of folks feel the way you do about having time, but not money.

However, I would like to point out that there are also a lot of people (businesses/organizations) that have money, but don't have time or knowledge.

For this reason, I am advocating for a way to allow those who want to provide financial assistance for core, contribs or even custom, the ability to give back.

If the only way a person, organization or business can give back is through financial assistance, but there is no way for them to do so, they don't end up giving back at all. This hurts the community.

Let's take Ubercart as an example because that's what I use. I would gladly pay for additional features or support on that module because it benefits me. However, I wouldn't necessarily give back to core because that's not where my problem is. I'm left with hiring a third party developer to fix my problem and never give that back to the community because a) the maintainer doesn't want to mess with adding the fixes or b) I don't have time to add it as a contrib and then try to maintain it.

I strongly believe it hurts the community more than it helps and have observed this over the last 13+ years with Drupal.

Just so we're clear, I'm not advocating for a subscription model, or commercial model (though yes, I have suggested those options and they are widely not popular for good reason).

The option I think a lot of folks can get on board with is a "donation" model where the ability to give back is available, but completely optional.

There are a LOT of things to work out, but I think it is the most forgiving to keeping the entire platform and codebase free, but still opening an avenue for a lot of the community to give back who would otherwise never give back.

If this whole monetization thing moves forward, Backdrop needs to set the standards of what it will look like and what is expected. For example, don't come here thinking you're going to make money because that's not how it works. You come here because you want to be passionate about the project. Any funds you receive are a "thank you" from the community and gives you a reason to focus back on that project because others are also passionate about your work and want to see it continue to move forward.

Drupal did a great job of creating a friendly, helpful community. Backdrop is doing the same. It's the expectations of the community that molded it, and adding a monetization scheme would be no different. We just have to mold the expectation which is a lot easier when the community is small. The larger it becomes, the more difficult it is to set the expectation.

I know, I shouldn't,... but can't resist to share some general thoughts about Open Source...

In the Open Source ecosystem it's not uncommon that maintainers (or engaged contributors) leave a project. There are many possible reasons for that - change of interest, lack of time...

A proprietary (closed source) software project would certainly die with that, but not necessarily an Open Source project. Why? Because the source code is available, and anyone can fork it. If there's an interested community, someone with sufficient skills can take over. I saw this happen many times.

So my conclusion: it's mainly the availability of source code, that can guarantee the continuation of a project. Given that enough people are interested in the project. Payment can be nice, but is secondary IMO.

As for the above particular opinion of @klonos I do really disagree, because there are plenty of Drupal 7 projects which rely on specific contributed or custom modules and if their owners decide to financially support development of only those Backdrop projects which they need and which not necessarily fall into "non-80%" category, then it's really nobody's, but their only business. It's not really about getting those kind of projects into core or letting people/entities with money influence decisions about Backdrop project. The community can be safely growing further within the principles set by the current project leads, however at the same time I believe it would be a really big mistake to push away any parties which would like to start financially supporting - core, contributed modules, themes or whatever they only need - really doesn't matter.

Let's just be open-minded and explore all kind of possibilities. I said it before and I will keep repeating: Backdrop have a realistic chance to beat WordPress! However, to do so the decision-takers in Backdrop community need to be really agile.

That means I'll help 'fund' backdrop by doing work my clients need done, then contributing that work to make backdrop better. I work within the framework, so everything I do would be 'selfish' (its not really 'for the good of the community', it's because I make money, my clients get websites), but at the same time its good for backdrop.

I guess I'd say dont assume everyone wants to help backdrop for the sake of backdrop (writing off those who contribute for 'selfish' reasons). Most 'commercial' devs will help because its good for them AND for backdrop. I want backdrop to succeed because it's good for me AND good for the community. Personal opinion: I'm not against people getting paid for developing modules but I am against an ecosystem that encourages separate payments (especially recurring subscriptions) for each module needed, with each developer trying to build their own monetized silo in one way or another. Heavily in favor of people getting paid to spend time improving a module and then releasing those improvements to the project/module without additional fee. Relatedly, I'm also not a fan of Freemium/Premium type plugins that try to bait and switch.
